hints_html: A function is undefined if it has a zero in the denominator.
hints_latex: A function is undefined if it has a zero in the denominator.
hints_raw: A function is undefined if it has a zero in the denominator.
question: 9 (a)
sols_html:
The domain of a function is the set of all values where the function is defined. The function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{x+1}{x-1}\end{aligned}\]

is defined everywhere except where its denominator is equal to zero. Setting the denominator equal to zero and solving...

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x - 1 = 0\end{aligned}\]

gives that the denominator is zero when \(x = 1\). Thus \(f(x)\) is defined everywhere except \(x = 1\). In interval notation this is written \((-\infty, 1)\cup(1, \infty)\), or, equivalently

\[\begin{aligned} (-\infty,\infty) \backslash \{1\}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The domain of a function is the set of all values where the function is defined.  The function

:<math>f(x) = \frac{x+1}{x-1}</math>

is defined everywhere except where its denominator is equal to zero.  Setting the denominator equal to zero and solving...

:<math>\displaystyle x - 1 = 0</math>

gives that the denominator is zero when <math>x = 1</math>.  Thus <math>f(x)</math> is defined everywhere except <math>x = 1</math>.  In interval notation this is written <math>(-\infty, 1)\cup(1, \infty)</math>, or, equivalently

:<math> (-\infty,\infty) \backslash \{1\} </math>
statement_html:
Let \(f(x) = \frac{x + 1}{x - 1}\).

State the domain of \(\displaystyle f\).
statement_latex:
Let $f(x) = \frac{x + 1}{x - 1}$.

State the domain of $\displaystyle f$.
statement_raw:
Let <math>f(x) = \frac{x + 1}{x - 1}</math>.

State the domain of <math>\displaystyle f</math>.
